units.title: Label Transwell plates for organoid generation
units.text: Day 13: on day 13 of monolayer differentiation, label the required number of six-well Transwell plates for organoid generation. If performing PT functionality assays and immunofluorescence outlined below, 2.5 Transwell plates will be required.
units.rationale: Identifies the plates needed before cell harvesting.

units.title: Detach cells with TrypLE Select
units.text:
Aspirate the CDBLY2 medium from each well of differentiated hPSC, wash with 1 mL/well of room temperature TrypLE Select, then aspirate and replace with a fresh 1 mL of TrypLE Select.
Incubate plate at 37 °C for 3 min.
While the cells are incubating, place 1 mL of room temperature E6 containing 2 % FBS into a 15 mL conical tube (one tube for every three or four wells of a 12‑well plate).
Gently detach the cells from the well surface by pipetting up and down a maximum of six times using a P1000 pipette, dissociating to a single‑cell suspension.
units.rationale: Provides the enzymatic and mechanical steps to obtain a single‑cell suspension.

units.title: Collect cells and centrifuge
units.text:
Transfer the cells in TrypLE Select to the 15 mL conical tube containing E6/2 % FBS.
Rinse the wells with an additional 1 mL of E6/2 % FBS to collect any residual cells and add to the same conical tube.
Top‑up the conical tube volume to 5 mL with E6/2 % FBS and centrifuge the tube at 300 g for 3 min.
Aspirate the supernatant and gently flick the tube three times to dislodge the cell pellet.
Resuspend the cell pellet to a final volume of 2 mL of E6/2 % FBS final volume, adding the medium gradually with a P1000 pipette and gently triturating the pellet during medium addition to resuspend to a single‑cell suspension using minimal pipetting.
units.rationale: Centrifugation concentrates the cells and prepares a uniform suspension for counting.

units.title: Count cells and calculate required volume
units.text:
Immediately remove 10 µL of the cell suspension for counting with a hemocytometer. Typically, prolonged differentiation in CDBLY2 will yield 5 × 10⁶ cells per well. A minimum of 11.25 × 10⁶ cells will be required for 45 organoids to perform both PT functional assays and immunofluorescence outlined below.
Calculate the cell suspension volume required for 250,000 cells and dispense this volume into individual 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tubes, allowing one tube per organoid (Fig. 1). For the generation of 45 organoids, we recommend preparing two or three extra tubes of 250,000 cells in case the cell micromass breaks during aspiration.
units.rationale: Ensures the correct number of cells are allocated per organoid.

units.title: Prepare micromass tubes
units.text:
Top up the medium volume in each tube to 200 µL with E6/2 % FBS.
Centrifuge tubes three times at 300 g for 3 min, rotating the tubes 180° between each centrifugation step. While centrifugation can be performed in two batches if only a 24‑tube rotor is available, it is preferable for all tubes to be centrifuged simultaneously, either by using two centrifuges or a larger capacity rotor.
▲ CRITICAL STEP If centrifugation is to be performed in batches, begin transferring the first batch of cell micromasses to the Transwell inserts (Step 46) while the second batch is underway to minimize delay.
units.rationale: Creates compact micromasses ready for seeding onto Transwell membranes.

units.title: Transfer micromasses to Transwell inserts
units.text: Transfer three micromasses to each Transwell insert, working swiftly without delay. Ensure minimal medium carryover by allowing each micromass to settle into the pipette tip opening before dispensing in a single droplet that is touched onto the Transwell membrane.
units.rationale: Places the cell aggregates onto the scaffold for 3D organoid formation.

units.title: CHIR pulse of micromasses
units.text: Once all cell micromasses have been added to the membranes, perform a CHIR pulse by adding 1 mL of E6‑containing 5 µM CHIR99021 to the base of the Transwell and incubating the cell micromasses for precisely 1 h in the 37 °C incubator.
units.rationale: Temporarily activates WNT signaling to promote nephron patterning.

units.title: Replace medium with FGF9/heparin
units.text: Following the CHIR pulse, replace the medium with E6 containing 200 ng/mL FGF9 and 1 µg/mL heparin to initiate organoid patterning.
units.rationale: Provides growth factors that drive metanephric mesenchyme maturation.

units.title: Culture organoids to day 18
units.text:
Culture the organoids for 5 d (to day 18), replacing the E6/FGF9/heparin medium once on day 3 post‑organoid generation (day 16).
Day 18: on day 5 post‑organoid generation (day 18), change the culture medium to E6 (without FGF9 or heparin).
units.rationale: Allows organoids to mature while gradually withdrawing patterning cues.

units.title: Fix organoids with PFA
units.text:
Day 27: set aside two plates (12 wells) of organoids for PT functionality assays (albumin and DAPI uptake, detailed in Steps 52–59 and 60–71) and remove the remaining plate of three wells from the incubator to undergo fixation for later immunofluorescence.
For fixation, aspirate medium from the base of the transwell and replace with 1 mL per well of cold 4 % PFA, also adding one drop of PFA on top of each organoid. Incubate the plate for 30 min at 4 °C, then remove PFA using a P1000 pipette and discard in the appropriate PFA waste container. Wash three times with PBS, 10 min per wash in the same manner as fixation, adding 1 mL of PBS to the basolateral Transwell compartment and one drop on top of each organoid.
units.rationale: Preserves organoid structure and antigenicity for downstream imaging.
